mmc1 mmc1.docx docx 1060206 APPLICATION MCAT 115372 115372 S2468-8231(25)00559-0 10.1016/j.mcat.2025.115372 The Author(s) Scheme 1 Reaction network of GUA hydroconversion on (A) non-acidic and (B) Lewis and/or Brønsted acidic oxide supported Ni catalysts. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 XRPD patterns of the Ni/SiO2, Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni/H-Beta and Ni/SAPO-11 catalysts: (A) air-calcined at 450 °C, (B) and subsequently reduced ex situ in H2-flow at 450 °C for 2 h, (C) reduced in situ in the catalytic reactor at 450 °C for 2 h then used for GUA hydroconversion at 300 °C for 37- 40 h. Fig 1 Fig. 2 TEM image of (A) Ni/SiO2, (B) Ni/γ-Al2O3, (C) Ni/H-Beta and (D) Ni/SAPO-11 catalysts reduced in H2 at 450 °C for 2 h. Fig 2 Fig. 3 H2-TPR profiles of the Ni/SiO2, Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni/H-Beta and Ni/SAPO-11 catalysts. The TPR curves were obtained by heating up the oxidized samples in a flow of 10.0 vol % H2/N2 mixture at a ramping rate of 10 °C⋅min−1 up to 800 °C (A). In a similar experiment, the samples were first reduced in the same reducing gas mixture up to 450 °C (B1), then cooled to 40 °C, and in a subsequent TPR run, the samples were reduced again up to 800 °C (B2). Fig 3 Fig. 4 FT-IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine on activated SiO2, γ-Al2O3, H-Beta and SAPO-11 supports (A) and on the reduced Ni/SiO2, Ni/H-Beta, Ni/γ-Al2O3 and Ni/SAPO-11 catalysts (B). Before pyridine adsorption, the supports were evacuated in high vacuum at 450 °C for 1 h. The supported Ni catalysts were reduced in H2 at 450 °C for 1 h, then evacuated at the same temperature. Adsorption of Py was carried out by contacting the activated samples with gas phase pyridine at about 5 mbar at 200 °C for 30 min, then evacuated at the same temperature (a) and subsequently at 400 °C for 30 min (b). The spectra were recorded at room temperature. L and B represent the characteristic bands of pyridine bound to Lewis or Brønsted acid centers, respectively. Spectra are normalized to a wafer “thickness” of 5 mg⋅cm–2. Fig 4 Fig. 5 GUA conversion and product yields on Ni/SiO2 catalyst at reaction temperatures between 225 and 300 °C. Reaction conditions: 10 bar total pressure, W/F = 1 gcat.⋅gGUA –1⋅h, H2/GUA=20 mol/mol. (MCHL: 2-methoxycyclohexane-1-ol; CHL: cyclohexanol; CHN: cyclohexanone; BEN: benzene; CHA: cyclohexane; Others include mainly pentane, hexane, and methylcyclopentane, and also includes 4–14 % methane). Fig 5 Fig. 6 GUA conversion and yield of products formed on Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at reaction temperatures between 225 and 350 °C. Reaction conditions: 10 bar total pressure, W/F = 1 gcat.⋅gGUA –1⋅ h, H2/GUA=20 mol/mol. (CHA , BEN, and CHL derivatives mean reaction products cyclohexane, benzene, cyclohexanol and their methyl-substituted derivatives; Other minor products include methylguaiacol and dimethoxybenzene below 250 °C, and 2–5 % methane + methanol). Fig 6 Fig. 7 GUA conversion and yields of products formed on Ni/H-Beta catalyst at reaction temperatures between 250 and 350 °C. Reaction conditions: 10 bar total pressure, W/F = 1 gcat.⋅gGUA –1⋅ h, and a H2/GUA=20 mol/mol. Results shown were obtained after reaching steady state conversion level at 18–19 h time-on-stream. (CAT, PHE, BEN, and CHA derivatives mean catechol, phenol, benzene, and cyclohexane and their methyl-substituted derivatives; trace amount of cyclohexanone (CHN) was also detected, Other minor products involve mainly methylated guaiacol, and methoxy‑ and dimethoxybenzene compounds, and 1–3 % methane). Fig 7 Fig. 8 GUA conversion and yields of products formed on Ni/SAPO-11 catalyst at reaction temperatures between 250 and 350 °C. Reaction conditions: 10 bar total pressure, W/F = 1 gcat.⋅gGUA –1⋅h, H2/GUA=20 mol/mol. Results shown were obtained after reaching steady state conversion level at 18–19 h time-on-stream. (PHE, BEN, and CHA derivatives mean phenol, benzene, and cyclohexane and their methyl-substituted derivatives; trace amount of cyclohexanone (CHN) and catechols (CAT) were also detected, Others involve mainly cyclopentane, methylcyclopentane, 1,1′-bicyclohexyl, and methoxy‑ and dimethoxybenzene, and 2–7 % methane). Fig 8 Table 1 Physical-chemical properties of the supports and the supported Ni catalysts. Table 1 Support/ Catalyst Ni, a wt % SSA, b m2⋅g–1 Reduction, c %,up to dNi, e dNi, f nm H2 uptake, g μmol H2/μmol Ni Acid sites, h μmol⋅g–1 450 °C 800 °C Brønsted Lewis SiO2 – 373 – – – – – – – Ni/SiO2 6.0 (5.9) 252 90 99 12 (13) 10 0.056 – 44 (22) γ-Al2O3 – 222 – – – – – – 180 (47) Ni/γ-Al2O3 5.3 (5.2) 220 4.8 99 n.d. 5 0.036 – 188 (68) H-Beta – 628 – – – – – 713 (375) 315 (313) Ni/H-Beta 5.3 (5.1) 563 68 92 15 (21) 10 0.011 469 (158) 279 (276) SAPO-11 175 – – – – – 9 (2) 32 (11) Ni/SAPO-11 5.4 (5.3) 121 91 147 d 26 (27) 20 0.049 2 (0) 105 (63) a Ni content of the fresh catalyst measured by ICP-OES method. The Ni content in the spent catalysts measured after 30 - 40 h operation in the hydroconversion reaction of GUA is given in parentheses. b The BET Specific Surface Area (SSA). c Degree of reduction determined from the H2-TPR measurements. d The reduction degree exceeding 100 % for the Ni/SAPO-11 sample suggests that not only Ni2+ was reduced to Ni0, but also a partial reduction of the AlPO4 units in the SAPO-11 structure occurred [52,53]. e Average diameter of Ni0 crystallites determined from the XRPD patterns of the reduced fresh and spent (in parentheses) Ni catalysts. f Average diameter of Ni0 particles determined from the TEM images of the reduced catalysts. g Hydrogen uptake of the Ni catalysts (determined by H2-TPD) relative to the Ni content. h The number of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites determined from the FT-IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine. Data were obtained after degassing the pyridine-loaded support or the reduced Ni catalyst at 200 °C and then at 400 °C. The concentration of strong acid sites (in parentheses) were calculated from the spectrum obtained after evacuation at 400 °C. Ni catalysts with ∼5 wt% Ni content were prepared using SiO2, γ-Al2O3, zeolite H-Beta, and SAPO-11 as supports and studied in the hydroconversion of guaiacol (GUA) in a solvent-free, continuous flow-through catalytic system. The acidity of the catalyst was found to direct the reaction towards different dominant reaction pathways. Over the virtually non-acidic Ni/SiO2 catalyst, the reaction was initiated by the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, followed by hydrogenolysis reactions giving cyclohexane, methane and methanol as main products. Over γ-Al2O3 and zeolite catalysts with Lewis and/or Brønsted acidity, the reaction was initiated by facile acid-catalyzed transmethylation reactions followed by metal-catalysed hydrogenation and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reactions. An O-free liquid product was obtained containing substantially all of the GUA carbon in methyl-substituted 6-membered carbocyclic moieties. The Brønsted acid catalysts are unfavorable due to their high activity in aromatic condensation reactions leading to coke deposition and rapid loss of activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Guaiacol Supported Ni catalysts Hydrogenolysis Hydrodeoxygenation Transmethylation Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction Bio-oils, produced from lignocellulosic biomass by thermal processes such as pyrolysis or liquefaction, have been recognized as a promising renewable source of fuel additives and fine chemicals [1–4]. Lignin represents 15–30 wt % of lignocellulose. It is produced in large quantities as a by-product of the pulp and paper industry and the cellulosic ethanol industry [5–8]. Lignin is an amorphous polymer composed of p-coumaryl, coniferyl and sinapyl alcohol monomers. The oils obtained from lignin depolymerization consist mainly of oxygenated aromatic compounds [1,9,10]. However, these oils have a low calorific value, and show unfavorable high viscosity, high water content, and corrosive properties due to their high oxygen content and therefore require upgrading before use or storage [7,11–13]. Catalytic hydroconversion involving hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a suitable method of removing all or part of the oxygen from oils to produce more valuable products [6–8,12,14]. Guaiacol (GUA, 2-methoxyphenol), a major component of oils obtained from lignin depolymerization, is an often-used model compound to study the HDO reactions of bio-oils. It contains hydroxy and methoxy functional groups commonly observed in lignin-derived bio-crudes [12–15]. Depending on the applied catalyst and the reaction conditions, the hydroconversion of GUA can lead to partially and fully deoxygenated compounds [7,8,12,14]. Fully saturated and deoxygenated products such as cyclohexane and methyl-substituted cyclohexanes can be used as fuels or solvents [12]. Aromatic products, such as benzene, toluene and xylenes (BTX) can be used as precursors for important fine chemicals and polymers, and as liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHC) [16,17]. Partially deoxygenated products, such as cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol are used as precursors for nylon in the polymer industry [12,18], phenol and its derivatives serve as precursors for a wide range of drugs, herbicides, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals and plastics [12], while hydrogenation of the GUA ring gives 2-methoxycyclohexane-1-ol, a suitable intermediate for the synthesis of a variety of value added products, such as antibacterial drugs, biologically active compounds and chiral molecules [19]. Directing the hydroconversion reaction of GUA towards the desired product(s) requires mostly the proper tailoring of the catalytic properties. Hydroconversion reaction includes hydrogenation reactions (mainly the saturation of the aromatic ring and the olefinic intermediates occurring in the course of the reaction) and HDO reactions [6–8,12–14]. In the commonly used temperature range (200–500 °C), hydrogenation reactions are controlled by the hydrogenation–dehydrogenation equilibrium [17,20], whereas thermodynamics does not limit the extent of HDO reactions involving cleavage of the CO bonds in GUA. Note that these primary reactions are often coupled by secondary conversion of the primary products, resulting in more complex product distributions [8,12,13]. The cleavage of the CO bonds can be effected by an active metal component of the catalyst via hydrogenolysis reaction; however, acid sites, if present, can also facilitate the breakage of the CO bonds [14,21–23]. The dissociation energies of the different CO bonds in GUA suggest that demethylation is preferred over demethoxylation, while the cleavage of the phenolic CO(H) seems to be the most difficult [12,24–26]. Note that saturation of the aromatic ring decreases the strength of all CO bonds, but their order of strength remains the same [6]. For the hydroconversion of GUA, a variety of monofunctional and mainly bifunctional metal-based catalysts have been used [6,18,21,25,27–41]. Noble metals and other transition metals including Ni, Co, Cu, Fe, Mo with hydrogenation/dehydrogenation activity supported on neutral supports, e.g. on virtually non-acidic SiO2, can be considered as monofunctional catalysts, whereas the application of acidic supports with Brønsted and/or Lewis acidity, e.g., H-zeolites, SiO2-Al2O3, sulfated ZrO2-CeO2 mixed oxides and Lewis acid γ-Al2O3, leads to bifunctional catalysts containing both hydrogenation and acidic catalytic functions. Supported noble metals show excellent catalytic activity in HDO reactions, but their high cost hinders their widespread industrial application. Some non-precious metal catalysts, such as supported Ni catalysts and their promoted bimetallic derivatives showed promising HDO potentials [12–14,22,27]; therefore Ni, which is relatively cheap and has favorably high hydrogenation activity, is often selected as the active metal component as it was also used in the present study. The selectivity of bifunctional catalysts can be controlled via regulating the hydrogenation and the acid functions of the catalyst [12–14,18,27,40–43]. As both of these catalytic functions can catalyze the cleavage of CO bonds, it is usually difficult to distinguish the contribution of the hydrogenation and the acid functions to HDO reactions. The formation of methyl or methoxy‑substituted products due to transmethylation, transmethoxylation and dispropotionation reactions [44–47] clearly indicate the involvement of acidic sites in the cleavage of OCH3 and CAr–OCH3 bonds (where CAr is the aromatic carbon). The lack of carbon loss in the overall reaction indicates that the activation of GUA takes place at the acid sites, whereas the significant formation of light products such as methane and/or methanol suggests the dominance of the hydrogenolysis reactions [48]. Also note that the rate of the metal-catalysed and acid-catalysed reactions show different dependencies on the reaction parameters; therefore, the application of optimized reaction conditions is also crucial to achieve high selectivity towards the desired product(s), especially by controlling the reaction temperature and H2 partial pressure [12–14,18,27,42,43,49]. The above problems make it difficult to design a catalyst with the required catalytic selectivity towards the desired product(s). Control of the hydrogenation function can be achieved by adjusting the size and amount of metal particles, as well as via controlling the interaction at the metal-support interface [12–14], while the required acidic function can be achieved by choosing a suitable solid acid catalyst support and/or tuning the acidity of the support material. Previous studies clearly indicate that the type, concentration, strength, and accessibility of acid sites can play a crucial role in product selectivity [21–24,49], although the relationships are far from being fully understood. In a recent study [48], we investigated the hydroconversion of GUA over γ-Al2O3 and phosphatized γ-Al2O3 supported Ni catalysts and found that phosphatization significantly reduced the concentration of Lewis acid (Al+)-Lewis base (O–) pair sites originaly present in the γ-Al2O3 support, thereby significantly suppressing the HDO activity of the catalyst. From these results, it can be concluded that the acidity of the support may have a controlling effect on the activity and selectivity of the catalyst, which deserves further investigation. In order to further clarify how acidity affects product selectivity in GUA hydroconversion, Ni catalysts supported on a virtually non-acidic (SiO2), Lewis acidic (γ-Al2O3, high surface area) and Brønsted/Lewis acidic (H-Beta and H-SAPO-11 zeolites) support material were investigated in the present work. The radically different catalytic behaviors could be primarily associated with the differences in the acid-base properties of the supports, involving the type, concentration and strength of the acid sites. It is also shown how the reaction pathways for the GUA HDO reaction were influenced by the support acidity in the studied supported Ni catalysts. The effect of reaction parameters on the catalytic properties, including the stability of the catalysts was also investigated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of the catalyst samples Commercial silica (CAB-O-SIL, H5), γ-Al2O3 (Alfa Aesar, high surface area), zeolite H-Beta (VALFOR® CP, Si/Al = 12.5, PQ Corp.) and SAPO-11 were used as supporting materials for the preparation of supported Ni catalysts. The SAPO-11 sample was prepared in our laboratory by using the modified synthesis method of Prakash et al. [50]. The synthesis gel comprised of aluminum hydroxyacetate (Merck), orthophosphoric acid (Merck, 85 %), silica sol (Ludox TMA, 34 %), dipropylamine template (Merck) and distilled water with the molar composition of 1.0 Al2O3 : 1.0 P2O5 : 0.08 SiO2 : 2.6 dipropylamine : 42 H2O. The gel was pretreated hydrothermally at 145 °C for 92 h. The as-synthetized product was washed with distilled water and calcined in air at 540 °C for 3 h to eliminate the residual organic template. The four supports are designated as SiO2, γ-Al2O3, H-Beta and SAPO-11. The nickel catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method. The supports were first dried at 110 °C for 12 h, then 9.5 g of dried supports were suspended in10 mL of an aqueous solution containing 2.473 g of nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Aldrich, 98 %) to obtain catalysts containing approximatelly 5 wt % Ni. The suspension was dried at 60 °C for 12 h before the solid was calcined at 450 °C for 4 h to decompose the Ni precursor compound. Before the catalytic run, the calcined catalysts were reduced in situ at atmospheric pressure in H2 flow at 450 °C for 2 h. The Ni catalyst samples are referred as Ni/SiO2, Ni/γ-Al2O3, Ni/H-Beta, Ni/SAPO-11 catalysts. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The Ni contents of the catalysts was determined by ICP-OES analysis method applying Spectro Genesis spectrometer (Spectro Analytical Instruments GmbH, Germany). The solid samples (20–25 mg) were digested in a solution containing 4.0 mL HNO3 (68 %) and 1.0 mL HF (40 %), using a microwave-assisted digestion apparatus (Anton-Paar, Multiwave 5000). The specific surface area (SSA) of the supports and the supported Ni catalysts were calculated from the N2 adsorption isotherms using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method. The isotherms were determined at the boiling point of liquid N2 (−196 °C) using an automated gas sorption apparatus (“Surfer”, Thermo Scientific). The samples were pretreated at 250 °C for 2 h under high vacuum (∼10−6 mbar) to remove adsorbed water from the solid before the experiment. The structure and crystalline phases present in the supports and the supported Ni catalysts were identified by a Philips PW 1810/3710 type powder diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator. Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) was applied. The X-ray tube was operated at 40 kV voltage and 35 mA current. The XRPD patterns were obtained using a scan step size of 0.02 degrees 2-theta and a scan time of 5 s in each step. A full profile fitting method based on the Scherrer equation was applied to determine the crystallite size of NiO in the calcined, and Ni0 in the reduced Ni catalysts, respectively. The reducibility of Ni-oxide species formed in the oxidized catalyst precursors was characterized by temperature-programmed reduction in H2 (H2-TPR method) applying a home-made apparatus. The catalyst precursor (about 100 mg) was pretreated in a 30 cm3⋅min−1 O2 flow at 450 °C for 1 h and cooled to room temperature. The calcined precursor was flushed with nitrogen and then heated to 800 °C at a temperature ramping rate of 10 °C⋅min−1 in a 10.0 vol % H2/N2 mixture (30 cm3⋅min−1) to obtain the H2-TPR curve. The TPR curve was also measured up to a reduction temperature of 450 °C to obtain information on the degree of reduction of the Ni species achieved during the reduction prior to the catalytic run (vide infra). The water formed during the reduction process was removed from the reactor effluent by passing the gas flow through a trap cooled by liquid nitrogen (−196 °C). The H2 consumption rate was measured by means of a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Cu(II)O was used for calibration. Sample morphology and metal particle size were characterized by Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). The powdered samples suspended in ethanol were dropcasted onto a coated copper grid (300 mesh). The TEM images were obtained by using a type of Morgagni 268D microscope operated at 100 kV and at a point-resolution of 0.5 nm. The hydrogen uptake of the Ni catalyst reduced at 450 °C was measured using the temperature-programmed desorption of H2 (H2-TPD method). The H2-TPR apparatus (vide supra) was used for these experiments. About 500 mg of the sample was reduced in a stream of H2 (30 cm3⋅min−1) at 450 °C for 1 h, then cooled to room temperature in the same flow. The sample was flushed with a N2 flow (30 cm3⋅min−1) to remove gas phase H2 from the system prior to starting the H2-TPD run, then the temperature was raised from room temperature up to 450 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C⋅min–1 to get the TPD curve. The changes in the H2 concentration during the measurement were followed by a thermal conductivity detector. The amount of desorbed H2 (μmol⋅gcat. –1) was calculated and related to the Ni content of the catalyst. The acidic properties of the SiO2, γ-Al2O3, H-Beta and SAPO-11 supports, as well as the corresponding Ni catalysts were characterized by Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy using pyridine (Py) as probe molecule. The experiments were carried out using a home-built in situ IR cell installed in a Nicolet Impact Type 400 spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The powdered catalyst sample was pressed into a self-supporting thin wafer and was placed into the sample holder of the cell. The oxide supports were activated at 450 °C for 1 h in a high vacuum (∼10– 6 mbar), while the supported Ni catalysts were first reduced in a H2 flow at 450 °C for 1 h, then evacuated in high vacuum at the same temperature. For the H-Beta-supported Ni catalyst, the oxidized precursor was also investigated and compared with the reduced form of the catalyst to identify the position of Ni species in the zeolite lattice/framework after oxidation and subsequent reduction steps. Spectra of the wafers, having a “thickness” of about 5 mg⋅cm–2, were collected at room temperature by averaging 32 scans at a resolution of 2 cm–1. The activated samples were exposed to Py vapor (5.7 mbar) at 200 °C for 30 min, then the Py-loaded wafers were evacuated in two consecutive steps at 200 and 400 °C for 30 min in each step. The spectrum of the Py-loaded sample was collected after each evacuation step. The difference spectrum, calculated as the difference of the spectra of the Py-loaded sample and the activated sample is characteristic of surface species from pyridine chemisorption on the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. Their concentrations were determined by calculating the integrated absorbance of the characteristic absorption band of pyridinium ion at 1540 cm–1 and the band of coordinated pyridine at 1450 cm–1. The integrated molar extinction coefficients used for calculating the concentrations were 1.07 and 1.65 cm⋅μmol–1 for the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, respectively [51]. The density of acid sites determined after evacuation in high vacuum at 200 °C and 400 °C is taken as the concentration of total and strong Brønsted and Lewis acid adsorption sites, respectively. A TG-MS analysis was performed to determine the amount of carbonaceous deposits on the spent catalysts. Measurements were carried out using a Setaram Labsys Evo (Lyon, France) TG-DSC system in a flow of high purity (99.999 %) synthetic air at a flow rate of 90 cm³⋅min–1. After the catalytic run, the samples were flushed with nitrogen (N2) for 30 min and cooled to room temperature (RT). The samples were weighed into 100-μL Al2O3 crucibles (the reference cell was left empty) and heated from 25 °C to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C⋅min–1. The data obtained was baseline corrected and further processed using the thermoanalyzer’s processing software (Calisto Processing, version 2.16). The thermal analyzer was calibrated using a multipoint calibration method with seven different certified reference materials to cover its entire operating temperature range. While the thermal measurements were being taken, the evolved gases/volatiles were analyzed using a Pfeiffer Vacuum Omni Star™ mass spectrometric evolved gas analysis system (MS-EGA). The gas splitter was thermostated at 220 °C, and the transfer line to the mass spectrometer was kept at 200 °C. Measurements were performed in SEM Bargraph Cycles acquisition mode with a continuous scan of the m/z interval 11–90 at a speed of 100 ms/amu. The spectrometer operated in electron impact mode. 2.3 Catalytic experiments The hydroconversion of guaiacol (GUA) was studied in a reactor system using a fixed-bed microreactor operated in continuous flow-through mode without solvent. The 0.315–0.630 mm sieve fraction of the catalyst grains was placed in a stainless steel reactor tube (ID= 12 mm). Before the catalytic experiment, the catalyst was reduced in situ in flowing H2 (100 cm3⋅min–1) at 450 °C for 2 h. A high pressure liquid pump (Gilson, Verity 3011) and a mass flow controller (Aalborg) were used to control the feed of guaiacol and hydrogen gas, respectively. The HDO of GUA was studied in the reaction temperature range of 225–350 °C and 10 bar total pressure. The space velocity of GUA was varied between 4.0 and 1.0 gGUA⋅gcat –1⋅h–1 (space time of 0.25–1.0 gcat⋅gGUA –1⋅h), while the molar ratio of H2 to GUA was kept at 20. Using 1.112 g of catalyst, the GUA feed and hydrogen flow rate varied between 4.0 and 1.0 mL⋅h−1 and 300 and 75 mL⋅min−1, respectively. After changing the reaction conditions, the steady state conditions were achieved whithin one hour. The details of the handling and analysis of the reaction products exiting from the catalytic reactor were given elsewhere [48]. Briefly, the effluent from the reactor passed through a condenser and a gas-liquid separator. The liquid product collected each hour was weighed on an analytical balance. The separated gas phase and liquid phase products were analysed by a GC-TCD and a GC–MS system, respectively by using the previously determined response factors for the main reaction products. Note that the gas product consited mainly methane (only trace amounts of other volatile componds were detected) and its amount is involved in the product distribution. The material balance determined from feed carbon content and reactor output differed by <5 % in each catalytic run. The experimental error is within the typical GC errors (ca. ±5 %). The conversion of GUA was determined as a ratio of mols of GUA consumed and mols of GUA fed in the reactor, whereas the yield of product i was calculated as the molar ratio of product i in the product mixture and GUA in the feed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical-chemical properties of the catalysts 3.1.1 Chemical composition and specific surface area The nickel content of the catalysts was 5.3–6.0 wt % (Table 1 ). The isotherms obtained on the four oxide carriers and the corresponding supported Ni catalysts are given in Fig. S1. The isotherms obtained for SiO2 and γ-Al2O3 and the corresponding Ni catalysts (Fig. S1A, B) are characteristic for mesoporous solids. Both isotherms are classified as type IV isotherm, with H1 and H2 type hysteresis loops for SiO2 and γ-Al2O3, respectively. For SiO2, the hysteresis loop appearing above p/p0 = 0.9 is due to the pores formed between the silica nanoparticles. The specific surface area (SSA) of SiO2 decreased by about 30 % upon Ni loading (Table 1), most probably due to the partial filling of the interparticle pores with nickel particles and/or to the agglomeration of nano-sized silica particles during the preparation of the Ni form. In contrast, neither the isotherm (Fig. S1B) nor the SSA (Table 1) for the γ-Al2O3 support changed after the introduction of 5 wt % Ni. Both the H-Beta zeolite and SAPO-11 exhibit type I isotherm characteristic of microporous solids. The latter sample shows a type H2 hysteresis loop (Figs. S1C, D) indicating that SAPO-11 also contains mesopores in the range of 3.5–15 nm. Relative to the corresponding properties of the zeolite H-Beta with three-dimensional, large micropores of 0.76×0.64 nm size, the SSA and micropore volume of the Ni-loaded zeolite Beta decreased slightly (Table 1). In contrast, loading the SAPO-11 zeolite, which has one-dimensional micropores of 0.39×0.63 nm size, with Ni resulted in a decrease of approximately 30 % in SSA and micropore volume, suggesting that the relatively large nickel particles (∼ 26 nm) could effectively block the micropores of SAPO-11. The Ni concentrations of the used catalysts were also determined. They were within the experimental error compared to the Ni content of fresh catalysts. There was virtually no metal leaching as the catalyst was in contact with the GUA vapor under the reaction conditions used. 3.1.2 Structural properties The XRPD patterns of the calcined, reduced, and used catalyst samples are shown in Fig. 1 . The characteristic diffraction lines in the diffraction patterns in Figs. 1A-C attributed to the supports are in good agreement with the reference ICDD data for γ-Al2O3 (00–010–425), zeolite beta (00–048–0074) and SAPO-11 (00–047–0614), whereas the broad diffraction line between 2θ = 10 and 35° is characteristic of amorphous silica. On the calcined silica-, zeolite-, and silicoaluminophosphate-supported Ni catalysts, a crystalline cubic nickel(II) oxide phase (bunsenite, ICDD 00–047–1049) was detected. Reflections of the NiO phase appear at 2θ = 37.1 (111), 43.3 (200) and 62.9° (220) (Fig. 1. A). The average particle size of NiO in the Ni/SiO2, Ni/H-Beta and Ni/SAPO-11 catalysts, was 17, 21, and 35 nm, respectively. In agreement with earlier results [48,51,54,55], a highly dispersed nickel(II) oxide phase with no long-range order was formed on the γ-Al2O3 support at low Ni content (∼5–6 wt %), which could not be detected by XRPD (Fig. 1. A). The formation of stoichiometric surface Ni-aluminate phase can be excluded, since the insertion of Ni2+ cations into the alumina structure requires a significantly higher temperature (>800 °C) than the calcination temperature used here (450 °C) during sample preparation. This highly dispersed NiO phase represents species that are difficult to reduce, as confirmed by H2-TPR measurements (vide infra). When the calcined Ni catalyst precursors were reduced at 450 °C, a cubic Ni0 metal phase (ICDD 00–004–0852) was detected in the X-ray diffraction patterns of the Ni/SiO2, Ni/H-Beta and Ni/SAPO-11 catalysts (Fig. 1. B). The diffraction lines of metal Ni0 phase appear at 2θ = 44.5 (111) and 51.9° (200). The calculated average crystallite size of Ni0 was 12, 15 and 26 nm for Ni/SiO2, Ni/H-Beta and Ni/SAPO-11, respectively, which agrees well with the values determined from TEM images (vide infra, Table 1). It should be mentioned that a nickel phyllosilicate phase (nickel silicate with a layered structure) could not be observed (Fig. 1). Its formation is very unlikely by using a simple wet impregnation method applied here, whereas deposition-precipitation method applied by Wang et al. [19] could lead to the formation of nickel phyllosilicate phase. The XRPD pattern of the reduced Ni/H-Beta shows that a small fraction (∼ 5 %) of Ni remained unreduced as shown by the low-intensity diffraction line characteristic of NiO phase (Fig. 1. B). In agreement with previous observations [48], no characteristic diffraction lines of the Ni0 phase were found in the XRPD pattern of the reduced Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 1. B). The H2-TPR results (vide infra) showed that only a small part (about 5 %) of the Ni content was reduced to Ni0 up to 450 °C (Table 1). The TEM image of the reduced Ni/γ-Al2O3 (vide infra) also confirmed that the concentration of the Ni0 is low, with a particle size of about 5 nm, and therefore not detectable by XRPD. The XRPD pattern of the used catalyst (Fig. 1. C) indicates that a slight sintering occurred on Ni/H-Beta (average Ni0 particles increased from 15 to 21 nm) during the 30–40 h catalytic run, whereas no discernible sintering could be detected for the other catalysts. 3.1.3 Ni particles detected by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) TEM images of the reduced Ni catalysts are presented in Fig. 2 . Metallic nickel particles could be detected on all supported Ni catalysts. Images of Ni/SiO2 and Ni/H-Beta and Ni-SAPO-11 catalysts show Ni0 particles with diameters of 10–12 (Fig. 2. A), 8–15 (Fig. 2. C) and about 20–30 nm (Fig. 2. D), respectively. These diameters are in harmony with the mean Ni0 diameters from the XRPD analysis (Table 1). Only very few and small (about 5 nm) Ni0 particles were discernible on the reduced Ni/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 2. B), which could not be detected by XRPD (Fig. 1. B). 3.1.4 Reducibility of nickel oxide species studied by H2-TPR The H2-TPR curves obtained on the calcined catalyst precursors are shown in Fig. 3 . The degrees of Ni reduction after reduction to 800 and 450 °C (Figs. 3A and B1) were calculated from the hydrogen consumption and the corresponding Ni content and are shown in Table 1. The degree of reduction of Ni up to 450 °C was determined, because the catalysts were in situ reduced at this temperature in an H2 flow prior to the catalytic run (Table 1). The H2-TPR curves of Ni/SiO2, Ni/H-Beta and Ni/SAPO-11 catalyst precursors show intense overlapping reduction peaks in the temperature range of 300 - 550 °C (Fig. 3. A). In contrast, the reduction of NiO on γ-Al2O3 starts above 360 °C, and most of the NiO can be reduced only at much higher temperatures between 470–800 °C (Fig. 3. A). The H/Ni atomic ratio determined up to 800 °C for the Ni/SiO2 and Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was 1.98, which correspond practically to the total reduction of Ni2+ species to Ni0 in these catalysts (Table 1). The H/Ni atomic ratio was 1.84 (reduction degree of 92 %) for the Ni/H-Beta (Table 1), indicating that some Ni2+ species, probaly occupying cationic positions are not reducible even up to 800 °C (vide infra) [56]. The hydrogen consumption of 2.94 H/Ni determined for the Ni/SAPO-11 sample significantly exceeded the theoretical value of 2.0 H/Ni (Table 1) suggesting that not only the Ni2+ species was reduced, but also the partial reduction of some AlPO4 units in the SAPO-11 structure contributed to the hydrogen consumption at high temperatures (>500 °C) in the presence of metallic Ni0 (Figs. 3A, B2) [52,53]. The reduction degrees determined up to 450 °C reduction temperature suggest that smaller or larger fraction of the Ni2+ species remained unreduced in the samples at the reduction temperature applied prior to the catalytic experiments (Table 1). The unreduced fraction of Ni is about 10 % in the Ni/SiO2 sample after reduction at 450 °C (Fig. 3. B1, Table 1). It has been reported that silica supported NiO, reducible up to about 500 °C, can be attributed to bulk NiO in weak interaction with the SiO2 support, whereas nickel oxide species reducible only above 500 °C are thought to exist either as hard-to-reduce small crystallites, surface nickel silicates, or hydroxysilicates [57]. Acidity characterization revealed that the nickel species remaining unreduced up to 450 °C and strongly interacting with the silica support can generate Lewis acid sites in our Ni/SiO2 catalyst (vide infra). A weak reduction peak at around 390 °C and overlapping broad reduction peaks between 470–800 °C appeared in the H2-TPR profile measured on Ni/γ-Al2O3 up to 800 °C (Fig. 3. A), while nearly full reduction of Ni was achieved (Table 1). However, <5 % of the Ni2+ species was reduced up to 450 °C (Table 1, Fig. 3. B1). Previous studies [58,59] revealed that bulk NiO clusters in weak interaction with the alumina can be reduced around 400 °C. In contrast, strongly interacting, highly dispersed nickel oxide species, as well as the non-stoichiometric nickel aluminate phases can only be reduced at significantly higher temperatures ranging from 450 to 750 °C, whereas stoichiometric NiAl2O4 phase, if present, can be reduced at even higher temperatures (>750 °C). Based on the above assignments, the high temperature reduction peaks observed on the Ni/γ-Al2O3 sample (Fig. 3. B2) can be attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed NiO and/or non-stoichiometric nickel aluminate phases. These results are in line with our previous observations on a similar catalyst preparation [48]. The H2-TPR profiles measured up to 800 °C for the Ni/H-Beta sample (Fig. 3. A) show broad overlapping reduction peaks between 350–700 °C with maxima at 394 and 456 °C and with a weak shoulder at about 600 °C. Reduction peaks observed between 350 and 450 °C on Ni/H-zeolite systems have been attributed to the reduction of NiO clusters in weak interaction with the zeolite support, whereas reduction peaks appearing over about 500 °C were attributed to the reduction of hard-to-reduce Ni species, such as ionic or neutral oxide-like species inside the zeolite channels and/or ionic Ni species in cationic positions [56,60,61]. For Ni/H-Beta reduced at 450 °C, a reduction degree of 68 % was achieved (Fig. 3. B1, Table 1). The Ni concentration in the catalyst was 852 μmol⋅g–1, whereas the unreduced fraction was 263 μmol⋅g–1. Considering that the concentration of the bridging OH groups in the Ni/H-Beta catalyst is lower by about 240 μmol⋅g–1 than in the pure H-Beta support, we can conclude that most of the Ni species that have not been reduced up to 450 °C are likely to be present as compensating cations in our Ni/H-Beta catalyst (Table 1, vide infra). The peak observed at around 600 °C (Fig. 3. B2) can be attributed to the partial reduction of cationic Ni2+ species and/or small NiO clusters located inside of the zeolite channels [56,62]. For the Ni/SAPO-11 sample reduced at 450 °C, a reduction degree of 90 % was achieved (Fig. 3. B1, Table 1) indicating that most of the Ni species were in the form of easily reducible NiO clusters weakly interacting with the SAPO-11 support. The unreduced fraction of the Ni species (∼10 %) probably occupies ion-exchange positions and/or present as oxide-like species within the zeolite channels as was substantiated for the H-Beta support. In addition, the presence of some Ni2+ species as surface nickel aluminate spinel phase formed by the interaction of Ni2+ with the silicoaluminophosphate support cannot be excluded [52,53]. 3.1.5 Acidic properties studied by pyridine adsorption The concentration of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites of the neat supports and the Ni catalysts were determined from the FT-IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine (Fig. 4 ). It has been shown that Py could form only H-bonded species interacting relatively weakly with the silanols on the surface of the non-acidic silica material [63,64]. In agreement with this observation, a pair of bands at 1446/1598 cm–1 assigned to the 19b/8a ring vibration modes of Py, H-bonded to silanols are visible after degassing up to 100 °C (Fig. S2). The interaction is weak, as these bands disappear already at 200 °C by evacuation (Fig. 4. A). In contrast, the spectrum of the reduced Ni/SiO2 catalyst shows low-intensity bands at approximately the same wavenumbers and component bands at somewhat higher wavenumbers (1450/1600 cm−1) after degassing at 200 °C (Fig. 4. B). These bands weakened at elevated degassing temperatures, but did not fully disappear even at 400 °C suggesting that Ni/SiO2 contains a few Py-bonding Lewis acid sites. The generation of these new Lewis acid sites is due to the strong interaction of the unreduced fraction (∼10 %) of NiO and the SiO2 surface (Table 1). The 19b/8a ring vibration modes of pyridine adsorbed on Lewis acid sites of the γ-Al2O3 support (Fig. 4. A) and Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 4. B) gave a pair of bands at 1455/1624 and second pair of bands at 1450/1615 cm–1 indicating the presence of two types of Lewis acid sites [65]. These Lewis acid sites have been attributed to coordinately unsaturated surface aluminum species in the alumina structure. The first pair of bands (1455/1624 cm–1) are characteristic of the strongest Lewis acid sites in γ-Al2O3, whereas the second pair of bands at 1450/1615 cm–1 probably indicates the presence of less acidic sites [65,66]. These latter adsorption sites are proved to be weaker Lewis acid centers because the corresponding pair of bands at 1450/1615 cm–1 disappear from the spectrum after evacuation at 400 °C. Consistent with our previous observations [48], the acidity of the catalyst remained practically unaffected after the introduction of 5 wt % Ni (Figs. 4A, B and Table 1). In the spectra obtained for H-Beta (Fig. 4. A), the appearance of a pair of bands at 1546/1637 cm–1, attributed to pyridinium ions formed on Brønsted acid sites, together with another pair of bands at 1455/1622 cm–1 attributed to Py coordinated to Lewis acid sites, confirms that H-Beta contains both types of acid sites (Table 1). It has been confirmed that Lewis acid sites in H-Beta zeolite can be mostly attributed to defective framework aluminum atoms attached to two or three [SiO4/2] tetrahedra in the zeolite structure [67], while extra-framework aluminum species (AlO+), the most common Lewis acid sites in zeolites, may contribute slightly to the 1455/1622 cm–1 band pair of adsorbed Py. For this catalyst, the oxidized precursor was also investigated and compared with the reduced form of the catalyst to identify the position of Ni species in the zeolite lattice/framework after oxidation and subsequent reduction at 450 °C (Fig. S3). In the spectrum obtained for the oxidized precursor of the Ni/H-Beta catalyst, the integrated absorbance of the νOH band at 3610 cm–1, assigned to bridging hydroxyls (Brønsted acid sites), was by about 85 % lower than that of the corresponding band of the H-Beta zeolite (Fig. S3A), suggesting that most of the protons in H-Beta were replaced by Ni2+ and/or Ni(OH)+ cations during sample preparation [62,68]. As expected, the intensity of the pyridinium (PyH+) bands of the oxidized precursor of Ni/H-Beta at 1546/1637 cm–1 was similarly lower than the corresponding band of the H-Beta zeolite (Fig. S3B). In addition, the concentration of Lewis sites associated with defective framework Al3+sites also decreased significantly as indicated by the intensity loss of the pair of bands at 1455/1622 cm–1 (Fig. S3B). The strong new pair of bands appearing at 1449/1609 cm–1 was assigned to Py coordinated to cationic Ni(OH)+ species [56]. The H2-reduction of the oxidized precursor of the Ni/H-Beta catalyst reconstructed a significant fraction of the Brønsted acid sites consumed in the ion exchange process as shown by the reappearance of the νOH band at 3609 cm−1 and the pyridinium ion bands at 1546/1637 cm−1 (Fig. S3), indicating that a large fraction (almost two third) of these cationic Ni species is reducible. The reduction of cationic Ni species also caused the partial regeneration of Lewis acid sites associated with defective framework Al3+sites shown by the reappearance of the Py bands at 1455/1622 cm–1 (Fig. S3B). Simultaneously, those Lewis sites associated with Ni(OH)+ were eliminated, as indicated the Py bands at 1449/1609 cm-1 (Fig. S3B). As a result of the above processes, the concentration of Brønsted acid sites in the reduced Ni/H-Beta catalyst was about one-third-of that in the H-Beta zeolite. The concentration of Lewis acid sites in Ni/H-Beta catalyst was about 10 % lower than in H-Beta zeolite (Table 1, and Figs. 4A, B). Note that significant fraction (∼30 %) of cationic Ni species could not be reduced at 450 °C, which also contributes to the Lewis acidity of the Ni/H-Beta catalyst. Above results show that the reduced Ni/H-Beta catalyst contains high amounts of strong Brønsted and Lewis acid sites. Insertion of Si into the framework of the aluminophosphate molecular sieves yields silicoaluminophosphate zeolites (SAPOs). The Brønsted acidity of SAPO-11 is due to the substitution of phosphorus (formal oxidation state of 5+) by silicon (formal oxidation state of 4+) in the framework, leading to the formation of negative framework charge compensated by protons. The weak PyH+ bands at 1546/1639 cm–1 in the spectrum of SAPO-11 (Fig. 4. A) suggest that the sample contains Brønsted acid sites in relatively low concentration. The two pairs of absorption bands (1455/1624 and 1450/1614 cm–1) indicate the occurrence of two types of Lewis acid sites (Fig. 4. A, Table 1). Introduction of Ni resulted in a lower number of Brønsted sites and increased number of Lewis sites in the Ni/SAPO-11 catalyst (Fig. 4. B, Table 1). The modified acid site distribution can be attributed to an ion-exchange process with nickel cations during the sample preparation process, although the blockage of the narrow, one-dimensional pore system of SAPO-11 by Ni0 species could also affect the acidity as suggested by Lyu et al. [53]. 3.2 Catalytic properties The silica (SiO2) showed no activity in the GUA hydroconversion reaction due to the lack of catalytically active acid sites (Table S1). The Ni/SiO2 catalyst had hydrogenation activity and catalyzed the benzene ring hydrogenation and also the hydrodeoxygenation reactions of the resulting intermediate compound (Fig. 5 ). At the lowest reaction temperature (225 °C), the saturation of the GUA ring gave methoxycyclohexanol (2-methoxycyclohexane-1-ol) as the main product. In secondary reactions, some of the methoxycyclohexanol was converted to cyclohexanol. In the function of space-time, the concentration of methoxycyclohexanol proceeds through a maximum, showing that methoxycyclohexanol was an intermediate in the formation of cyclohexanol (Fig. S4). Interestingly, no methanol was detected as a by-product, but methane was. The absence of 1,2-cyclohexanediol in the product mixture may indicate that hydrodemethoxylation occurred, but the by-product methanol did not maintain its integrity under these conditions, favoring hydrogenolysis (Fig. S4). It is more likely that the rate constant of 1,2-cyclohexanediol formation is much smaller than the rate constant of those reactions that consume the diol. The result is that the diol is not detectable in the product mixture. At elevated temperatures (>275 °C), the HDO reaction of cyclohexanol proceeds readily to give the O-free cyclohexane product (Fig. 5). The latter reaction can proceed via hydrogenolysis of the C–O(H) bond (hydrodehydroxylation) or, if acid sites are present, via dehydration of cyclohexanol to cyclohexene and the following hydrogenation of the double bond to cyclohexane (dehydration/hydrogenation pathway) [12–14]. The neat SiO2 support does not contain any catalytically active acid sites, but the unreduced fraction of the supported Ni generated some Lewis acidity in the Ni/SiO2 catalyst (Table 1), which are capable of catalyzing dehydration reactions. Although the concentration of Lewis acid sites in the Ni/SiO2 catalyst is relatively low, the dehydration/hydrogenation pathway may contribute to some extent to the HDO reaction of cyclohexanol to cyclohexane. The appearance of cyclohexanone as minor product in the product mixture (Fig. 5) also suggests that a reaction pathway involving a dehydration step on acid sites contributes to the deoxygenation reactions. The suggested pathway leading to cyclohexanone [21,29] involves the demethylation of methoxycyclohexanol intermediate to 1,2-cyclohexanediol, which can undergo dehydration on acid sites to give cylohex-1-en-1-ol and cyclohexanone intermediates via tautomerization, which are then hydrogenated to cyclohexanol. The formation of methoxycyclohexanol as the major intermediate suggests that the dominant pathway for the HDO reaction is initiated by ring hydrogenation on Ni/SiO2. However, the appearance of a small amount of benzene (Fig. 5) suggests that a minor pathway involving hydrodemethoxylation/hydrodemethylation and hydrodehydroxylation reactions leading to an unsaturated O-free product also occurs. At high reaction temperatures (>275 °C), ring-opening reactions of cyclohexane also occurred, giving mainly pentane and hexane products (Fig. 5, Table S1), which appear to be inevitable at elevated reaction temperatures over catalysts with high hydrogenolysis activity [29,39,69]. Importantly, the Ni/SiO2 catalyst exhibited good stability during the 40 h of operation due to suitable hydrogenation function (Fig. S5A). In contrast to the non-acidic SiO2 support, the Lewis acidic γ-Al2O3 support shows high GUA conversion activity (Table S1). Hydrogenation and HDO reactions obviously do not proceed in the absence of hydrogenation activity. The major products were catechol and methyl-substituted catechols (Table S1), indicating that transmethylation reactions, catalyzed by Lewis acid sites [44,45,47], predominate on the γ-Al2O3 support (see also in ref [48].). The reaction has been shown to proceed within an adsorption complex (intramolecular transmethylation) initiated by the heterolytic cleavage of the O–CH3 bond in the GUA molecule [45,46]. The concurrent formation of catechol and multiple methyl-substituted catechols together with a small amount of methyl-substituted guaiacols (Table S1) indicates that transmethylation occurred via both intramolecular and intermolecular pathways. In the presence of Ni and hydrogen, both hydrogenation and HDO reactions can readily proceed on the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 6 ). The substantial amounts of methyl-substituted derivatives among the reaction products (Table S1) implies that most of the methyl groups of the converted GUA were retained in the liquid product mixture. This is radically different from the Ni/SiO2 catalyst, where no methyl-substituted reaction products were formed (Table S1). The absence of the methyl-substituted products suggests that the relatively few Lewis acid sites, which were generated by the unreduced fraction of Ni on the silica support (Table 1), are not capable of catalyzing transmethylation reactions. In contrast, the Lewis acid sites, available in both the γ-Al2O3 support and the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (Table 1), can readily catalyze transmethylation reactions leading to methyl-substituted products. These results are consistent with those previously obtained with a similar Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst preparation [48]. It follows that the facile transmethylation reactions played a dominant role in the hydroconversion of GUA over the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, while hydrogenolysis reactions leading to demethylation or demethoxylation of the GUA molecule are minor reaction pathways. The nearly negligible contribution of the latter reactions is confirmed by the insignificant amount (<5 %) of methanol and/or methane in the product mixture. The intermediates with or without methyl groups, formed in the facile transmethylation reactions (mainly catechols) were further converted in ring saturation and/or hydrodehydroxylation reactions over the active Ni0 sites of the Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The main products were non-substituted and methyl-substituted cyclohexanols and cyclohexanes at relatively low reaction temperature (225 °C) (Fig. 6), where the hydrogenation–dehydrogenation equilibrium strongly favors ring hydrogenation [20]. The formation of O-free cycloalkane has been shown to proceed through a cyclohexanol intermediate over catalysts of high hydrogenation activity, such as supported noble metals or Ni catalysts [12,14,28]. Our results obtained as a function of space time at 225 °C (Fig. S6) are in agreement with the above notions. The GUA conversion and the yield of cyclohexanes raised concurrently, while the yield of cyclohexanols barely changed indicating that cyclohexanol(s) are intermediates of cyclohexane(s) formation. The appearance of unsaturated HDO products (benzene and methyl-substituted benzene derivatives) at higher reaction temperatures (>250 °C), where the ring hydrogenation becomes less favored [20], suggests that hydrodehydroxylation or tautomerization–hydrogenation–dehydration pathways [70,71] can also contribute to the HDO reaction. The absence of keto-tautomer or cyclohexadienol intermediate in the product mixture on our Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst suggests that the hydrodehydroxylation pathway is more likely. Note that hydrogenolysis of the C–O(H) bond, when the OH-group is linked to a saturated six-membered ring is more favored owing to the lower bond strength than that of the phenolic C–O(H) bond [6]. Hydrogenolysis of both the CO(H) bond attached to the saturated and unsaturated ring was significantly accelerated above 250 °C. Conversely, the formation of the saturated HDO products (cyclohexanes) became less favored at elevated reaction temperatures (>300 °C, Fig. 6), since the hydrogenation–dehydrogenation equilibrium favors the dehydrogenation of the six-member ring at high temperatures [20]. In line with our previous observations [48], these results show that the distribution of the products was controlled by the temperature dependence of the hydrodehydroxylation rate, as well as by the equilibrium of the ring hydrogenation–dehydrogenation. It should be mentioned that our Ni/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was considerably stable during the hydroconversion reaction of GUA up to about 40 h (Fig. S5B). The H-Beta zeolite catalyst containing both Brønsted and Lewis type acid centers (Table 1), shows little difference in activity and selectivity as compared to the Lewis acid γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The substantial formation of methyl-substituted products on H-Beta (Table S1) is in line with former observations that transalkylation reactions can proceed on both types of acid sites [45–47,72]. The dominance of methyl-substituted GUA products and methoxybenzenes suggests that transmethylation reactions on H-Beta proceeded mostly along intermolecular pathways. In presence of hydrogenation function, mainly hydrodehydroxylation reactions leading to phenol and its methyl-substituted derivatives proceed on the Ni/H-Beta catalyst, whereas ring hydrogenation leading to saturated products seems to be strongly suppressed (Fig. 7 ). It should be noted that the activity of the Ni/H-Beta catalysts dropped quickly at increasing time-on-stream (Fig. S5C, Table S1), therefore data obtained after reaching a steady state conversion level at 18–19 h time-on-stream are presented in Fig. 7. The fast activity loss can be attributed to the poisoning effect of polynuclear aromatics and graphitic coke deposition as their formation was obviously catalyzed by the Brønsted acid sites [13,14,72,73]. Coke deposition on the top or around the active metal sites probably hindered the accessibility of these sites and/or significantly poisoned their surface and thereby strongly suppressed the ring hydrogenation activity of the catalysts. In line with former observations [73], deposition of graphitic coke and polynuclear aromatics was clearly detected on our used Ni/H-Beta catalyst (Fig. S7–S9). The substantial concentration of the various methyl-substituted products detected among the reaction products obtained from GUA over the Ni/H-Beta catalyst (Table S1) suggests that the methyl groups remained in the GUA derivatives. The preservation of methyl groups suggests that the reaction intermediates formed in the facile transmethylation reactions on the Brønsted and/or Lewis acid sites (mainly catechols) were further transformed in hydrodehydroxylation reactions over some metal sites less affected by coke deposition in the Ni/H-Beta catalyst. Note that the latter hydrogenolysis reaction is probably less demanding than the ring hydrogenation reaction requiring multiple metal active sites. The conversion of GUA and the yield of phenol and methyl-substituted phenol compounds increased significantly at the expense of catechol and methyl-substituted catechols at elevated temperatures (>325 °C) due to the acceleration of the hydrodehydroxylation reaction (Fig. 7). The SAPO-11 catalyst containing Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in relatively low concentration (Table 1) show similar catalytic properties in the GUA conversion than the H-Beta catalyst (Table S1). The formation of methyl-substituted GUA products and methoxybenzenes as main products indicates the prevalence of intermolecular transmethylation reactions. The Ni/SAPO-11 catalyst is as susceptible to deactivation as the Ni/H-Beta catalyst. (Figs. S5C and D, Table S1). However, its hydrogenation activity, in particular its ring hydrogenation activity, appears to be less affected than that of the Ni/H-Beta catalyst, as evidenced by the more pronounced formation of saturated and unsaturated HDO products (cf. Figs. 7 and 8 ). These results suggest that poisoning of the active Ni0 centers due to the formation of carbonaceous depositions should be less significant, if the acidity of the catalyst is lower (Table 1). Infrared spectra confirmed that much less of graphitic coke and polynuclear aromatics were deposited on the used Ni/SAPO-11 than on the used Ni/H-Beta catalyst (Fig. S7). The TG-MS results (Fig. S8 and S9) are consistent with the FT-IR findings. The appearance of the CO2 signal in the mass spectrum (Fig. S9) above 300 °C confirms that coke deposits are removed within the temperature range of 300–650 °C. Approximately three times more coke formed on the Ni/H-Beta (17.4 wt. %) than on the Ni/SAPO-11 (5.0 wt. %), which contains Brønsted acid sites at a significantly lower concentration and acid strength (Fig. S8). The distribution of reaction products obtained on the Ni/SAPO-11 catalyst shows the pronounced formation of methyl-substituted products (Table S1, Fig. 8), indicating that the methyl groups of the converted GUA molecules were mostly retained in the liquid reaction products as it happened with the other studied bifunctional Ni-catalysts (see above). In the presence of Brønsted and/or Lewis acid sites, the reaction is initiated mainly by the facile transmethylation reactions giving intermediates consisting of non-substituted and methyl-substituted compounds containing 1–4 methyl substitution on the six-member ring. These intermediates are then further transformed to saturated and unsaturated HDO products via hydrogenation and HDO reactions over the active Ni sites. The above results substantiated that the acidity of the catalyst has a pivotal effect on the reaction pathways in the hydroconversion reaction of GUA as shown in Scheme 1 . Over non-acidic catalyst or even over catalyst with weak Lewis acidity, the GUA hydroconversion was initiated by ring hydrogenation, followed by hydrodemethoxylation/hydrodemethylation and hydrodehydroxylation reactions to give cyclohexane as main product (Scheme 1, section A). Most probably the weak Lewis acid sites also contributed to the deoxygenation by catalyzing the dehydration reaction of the 1,2-cyclohexanediol or cyclohexanol intermediate. In contrast, if the supported Ni catalysts had strong Lewis and/or Brønsted acidity, the GUA conversion was initiated by facile demethylation –methyl substitution (transmethylation) reactions, whereas hydrodemethylation and hydrodemethoxylation reactions represented only minor reaction pathways (Scheme 1, section B). The facile transmethylation reactions allow the preservation of the methyl groups of the GUA reactant in the O-free GUA derivatives formed in the subsequent hydrodehydroxylation and ring hydrogenation reactions [48]. It is important to emphasize that the strong Brønsted acidity of the catalyst promotes coke formation [73]. Catalyst coking can cause a significant activity loss and drop in the yield of the O-free HDO products. 4 Conclusions The effect of support acidity on the reaction pathways in the hydroconversion of GUA was investigated over Ni catalysts containing approximately the same amount of Ni (∼5 wt %) supported on oxide supports with different acidic properties. The Ni catalysts were prepared using a virtually non-acidic (SiO2) or Lewis acidic (γ-Al2O3) oxide support, as well as zeolite supports containing both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites at different concentrations (H-Beta, SAPO-11). The acidity of the support was found to play a crucial role, especially in the activation step of the GUA hydroconversion reaction. On the Ni catalyst supported on non-acidic SiO2 support, the reaction is initiated by ring hydrogenation of the GUA molecule followed by hydrodemethoxylation/hydrodemethylation and hydrodehydroxylation reactions to give cyclohexane as the main product. Methane and/or methanol appeared as products, reducing the carbon yield of the liquid GUA derivatives. In contrast, the hydroconversion of GUA is initiated by the facile demethylation–methyl substitution (transmethylation) reactions catalysed by the Lewis and/or Brønsted acid sites of the solid acid (γ-Al2O3, H-Beta or SAPO-11) supported Ni catalyst, while hydrogenolysis reactions resulting in demethylation or demethoxylation of the GUA molecule represent only minor reaction pathways. The facile transmethylation reactions lead to the formation of methyl-substituted and multi-methyl-substituted intermediates (1–4 methyl groups on the ring), thus allowing the preservation of the methyl groups in the liquid phase O-free GUA derivatives formed in the subsequent hydrodehydroxylation and ring hydrogenation reactions. Although both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites contribute to the transmethylation reactions, the presence of the latter type of acid site is not favoured. Brønsted acid sites are highly active in aromatic condensation reactions, leading to the deposition of polynuclear aromatics and graphitic coke and rapid poisoning of the active sites in the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Ni catalysts with ∼5 wt% Ni content were prepared using SiO2, γ-Al2O3, zeolite H-Beta, and SAPO-11 as supports and studied in the hydroconversion of guaiacol (GUA) in a solvent-free, continuous flow-through catalytic system. The acidity of the catalyst was found to direct the reaction towards different dominant reaction pathways. Over the virtually non-acidic Ni/SiO2 catalyst, the reaction was initiated by the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, followed by hydrogenolysis reactions giving cyclohexane, methane and methanol as main products. Over γ-Al2O3 and zeolite catalysts with Lewis and/or Brønsted acidity, the reaction was initiated by facile acid-catalyzed transmethylation reactions followed by metal-catalysed hydrogenation and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) reactions. An O-free liquid product was obtained containing substantially all of the GUA carbon in methyl-substituted 6-membered carbocyclic moieties. The Brønsted acid catalysts are unfavorable due to their high activity in aromatic condensation reactions leading to coke deposition and rapid loss of activity.
